content.description: Go up a steep bit via a nice finger crack that leaves you with a couple of slab moves to finish.  Short but it was always one of my favorites.  Don't you dare add a bolt to the finish!History:  John and Gahan's first try was defeated by yellow jacket stings.  John came back with a large amount of liquid pesticide and poured it down the route from above.  Then they led the route.  Talk about top-down route prep.....
content.protection: Pro to1"?  A good nut goes in right at the crack's end.  A cam would surely work but they weren't invented yet.
content.location: On the left side of Laddin's, right of So Low and left of the grassy section, rises a crack with no start or finish on a white-colored section of rock.

content.description:
Same start as Gorilla Traverse --(Climb the slab at the end of the wall before the base of the cliff starts going uphill to the walk-off. Traverse the horizontal crack to the left. Get high right feet until you can swing your legs over to the left to avoid the slippery bare section in the middle of the traverse. Use the undercling beneath small roof and/ or finger crack on the right side of the overhang to pull to a nice jug.)-- but continue traversing left past the big ledge. There is a good horizontal crack for an offset nut before you continue left. Follow the left upwards sloping crack, step out to a left foot, and pull a nice textured sloper to top out to the right of the bolted anchor for Off The Wall (12a).

 The horizontal crack is pretty dirty in some sections and can get muddy from run-off
content.protection: Finger size cams, a couple of yellow and a blue BDs; a blue DMM offset
content.location: This route is located at the far right end of the wall just before some nice boulders, where the ground starts to go up hill. A downed tree is a good seat for relaxing/ top rope belay spot. The first horizontal crack is easily spotted. Follow it right and you will see the slab you must climb to get onto the crack. The walk off is up and to the right if your heels were on the edge of the cliff.

content.description: Start on A Laddin Sane. Climb to the horizontal crack and break left for 10 ft. Then climb straight up passing a bolt, to a two bolt anchor. The R rating is only for the start of A Laddin Sane where there is no gear for the first ~15 feet. Otherwise the gear is great but a bit strenuous to place on the traverse.First ascent info: The horizontal crack was aided left to right in the 1970's by Johnson, Goolrick, and Haskins. The free variation was established by Vuono in Sept 2020.
content.protection: Small nuts and doubles on small cams (blue metolius, red C3 helpful) up to purple C4.
content.location: Same start as for A Laddin Sane

content.description: Route generally climbs diagonally up and right towards a VW Bug sized boulder perched atop the cliff.Begin about 15 feet left of the fall line dropping below perched boulder. Follow a crack / right slanting feature up through rounded bulge to rightmost of two trees on a ledge at 20 foot height. A few feet right of the tree, climb a crack through the smooth face leading up under the perched boulder.  Exit right under and around edge of the boulder to finish up.
content.protection: Traditional, no bolts.

climbs.name: Snot Nose
climbs.fa: TR: John Goolrick  FL: Felix Modugno, Harry Brielman early 1980's

content.description: Start on the bottom right of the main cliff, right of Gorilla Crack Start, climb the slab bottom, through a V-slot, to a nice ledge, then up the face or arete, passing a bolt that protects the crux. Fun variety of moves. This climb has been retrobolted to protect a ledge fall that was R/X. The two pitons previously fixed on the climb have also been removed. There is now gear placements where they used to be.
content.protection: 000 grey metolius/ purple C3 to 0.75 C4
content.location: On the right side of Laddin's Rock main cliff, 15 ft right of Gorilla Crack start before the hillside start going uphill

content.description: This route had been reclaimed by a carpet of moss as it last saw a thorough wire brushing almost 30 years ago.  It was re-cleaned in Nov. 2020.It is possible that this was scrubbed before the 90's and had reverted to moss, but the crumbling of key holds while working this route early on suggested that no one had yet climbed this line found left of the 5.12 Off The Wall.Once again prepped for climbing
content.protection: TR on extended slings from a tree

content.description: Boulder up past a seam right of First Aid to a stance below the headwall.  Hand traverse left to a ledge and scramble to the top.
content.protection: Pro to 2".
content.location: Right of First Aid, left of the gully.  This route is the same as First Responder, but goes left to the First Aid finish ledge instead of tackling the headwall.

content.description: Left to right traverse starting right facing side-pulls above the black graffiti. Stay high across the middle which has bad hands, good but hard to see feet and a rocky landing. Finish on the right side of the ramp.
content.protection: 1 pad
content.location: Ramp on the cliff-facing left side of Laddin’s, next to Scorpion. Start on the right facing side-pulls on the far left-side of the ramp.

climbs.name: Pullup
climbs.fa: Gahan Haskins, Chris Falkenstein, John Goolrick

content.description:
Climbs side pulls/undercling flakes and jugs to a slopped ledge into a  bulge/roof. 

  I have left the grade to be subjective and name unknown,until proper information is given from previous ascents.There are some small copperheads/old stoppers and fixed pins in various places that give confirmation of early ascents.
content.protection: Pad
content.location: On the very far right side of laddins near the walk up to the top.

climbs.name: Out to Lunch
climbs.fa: TR Gahan Haskins mid 1970's FLA Mack Johnson

content.description: The upper of the two traverse cracks on the Laddin's' main face.  Start on a short slab, climb a groove to a pedestal, protect, and launch.  Finish up a short hand-fist crack that is one of the finishes to Gorilla Traverse.
content.protection: cams to 3", some nuts.  Rope drag potential.
content.location: Right side of the main face, just before the cliff gets shorter.  Start is below an arête called Snot Nose (5.10+?)

content.description: Same start as for Out to Lunch and Snot Nose. Climb up the slab on the right side of the Main wall, through the flaring V-slot to a stance. Break left on the horizontal crack (same as Out to Lunch) but exit early before reaching the hand crack, climbing up a seemingly improbable face, protected on cams, to a two bolt anchor at the top of the cliff. First ascent info: The upper headwall may have been aid climbed previously.
content.protection: Single rack up to #2 C4. Save a 0.5-0.75 for the upper headwall.
content.location: Same start as for Out to Lunch and Snot Nose.

content.description: Follow the obvious crack up the right side of the ramp.
content.location: Right side of the ramp, next to “Scorpion”.

climbs.name: Off the Wall
climbs.fa: FA was A3 aid. Gahan Haskins, Chris Falkenstein and John Goolrick.

content.description: Climbs around laddins don't see much traffic so be weary of lichen/debry in cracks and on the face. The protection on this route is sparse, precise and small. Combined with the technical climbing, it would be a very strenuous committing proper lead (R/X) in its original state as a traditional crag (as pictured in my original pics) Currently, this route has been bolted and as a sport route. (6 bolts for 45ft of climbing 0_o......)
content.protection: 6 draws for this clip upA proper free ascent in its original natural state would require: RP's and small wires,c3 000 range cams
content.location: Towards the center of laddins crack

content.description: Follow shallow crack up to horizontal then flakes and exit right
content.protection: Toprope
content.location: On left end of ledge atop Laddins Traverse

content.description: Climb up cracks and jugs immediately to the left of the blue graffiti towards the highest point of the ramp. Tall warmup with a flat landing. Could use a good brushing.
content.location: Cliff-facing left side of the ramp.

content.description: Veasy-Vfun   Numerous variations are available to traverse or go straight up.
content.protection: Pad
content.location: On the very far right side of laddins before the walk up to the top.

climbs.name: Laddins Chimney/OW
climbs.fa: Gahan Haskins, Chris Falkenstein, John Goolrick

content.description:
Wide Chimney/OW,squeeze.Starts really wide,then narrows/flares. 

  I have left the grade to be subjective and name unknown,until proper information is given from previous ascents.There are some small copperheads/old stoppers and fixed pins in various places that give confirmation of early ascents.
content.location: Located on the right side of laddins rock,Next to untitled Pin face climb

content.description: Initial flakes lead slightly left up to first bucket marked by highest chalk mark in the photo. Intermediate moves bring you straight up to another great bucket about a foot below the top out. Reach up right to negotiate finish
Same start as Boof pack, but when you reach the last hold on the arete make a big move out left to a good pinch then fire to the lip to top out.
content.protection: 1 pad
content.location: same start as Boof pack.

content.description: Brian Drypolcher and I (John Goolrick) used an old trash can, to stand on and reach the obvious mantle, below the V slot gulley to the right of "First Aid." We did not have a rope and the rock was wet. A few years later, Haskins and I sent this free, and the the crux is right-off the ground, climbing thin-to-non-existent holds, up to the mantle.
content.protection: The crux is at the start and either a crash pad or spotter, would be appropriate, until you reach the upper 3rd of the climb where you can throw in a couple of nuts.
content.location: Laddin's Rock in Old Greenwich, Ct.  To the right of "First Aid."

climbs.name: Gorilla Traverse
climbs.fa: FA: John Goolrick and Gahan Haskins early 1970's, FFA: Goolrick

content.description: Climb the slab at the end of the wall before the base of the cliff starts going uphill to the walk-off. Traverse the horizontal crack to the left. Get high right feet until you can swing your legs over to the left to avoid the slippery bare section in the middle of the traverse. Use the undercling beneath small roof and/ or finger crack on the right side of the overhang to pull to a nice jug. Hammer out this section of upward right hand traversing to get to the big ledge. Power through short vertical wide hands crack to the top.
content.protection: .5'-3 Camelots are great. Nuts are helpful too on the upward right hand traverse. The rusty pitons do not look good. Two .5's is prime. There is a tree and or a large crack to build an anchor.
content.location: This route is located at the far right end of the wall just before some nice boulders, where the ground starts to go up hill. A downed tree is a good seat for relaxing/ top rope belay spot. The first horizontal crack is easily spotted. Follow it right and you will see the slab you must climb to get onto the crack. The walk off is up and to the right if your heels were on the edge of the cliff.

content.description: Start a few feet right of First Aid. Climb up flakes and crimps to a high first bolt. Supplement gear placements till the next bolt on the upper triangular headwall. Climb the headwall on the right arete, passing 3 bolts, to a two bolt anchor at the top of the cliff.First Ascent info: It is unknown if the upper headwall was previously aided or free climbed. Due to the lack of natural protection and some loose rock that was cleaned, this may be a first ascent.
content.protection: Bolts and gear: single rack, Yellow alien size to 0.75 C4, or optional number 3 C4. Stick clip might be useful.
content.location: Start 4 feet right of First Aid

climbs.name: First Aid
climbs.fa: FA: John Goolrick and Gahan Haskins early 1970's, FFA: Haskins and Goolrick mid 1970's

content.description: Climb the nice crack with good gear
content.protection: standard rack to .75  green camalot and a #3 blue camalot   Small to medium stoppers
content.location: Center right on laddins rock

content.description: Sit start with left and right hands on the arete, climb sharp crystals and small feet. Arete is off after the start
content.protection: 1 pad
content.location: East side of the Boof Pack Boulder, farthest from the cliff face.

content.description: Left-to-right traverse with the low start. First moves are the crux, especially for tall folks. Remember to be honest with yourself about dabbing the floor...
content.protection: 1 pad
content.location: All the way on the right hand side of the TR climbs, you pass by it on the walk around to the anchors

content.description: I believe this problem is called “cigarette” - sit start on the low right hand side pull and the left hand on the under cling. Stay right on the arête as you climb, topping out at the point of the arête.
content.protection: 1 pad
content.location: West side of the Boof Pack boulder, closest to the cliff face

content.description: Sit start with right hand on the arete and left hand on a small crimp. slap your way up the arete, using decent crimps on the left. finally rock over onto the slab to top out.
content.protection: 1-2 pads
content.location: The large boulder located at the bottom of the hill just past main wall. The climb starts on the right side of the sightly overhanging face

content.description: This is the obvious line drifting left and up through the middle of the Dinosaur Egg boulder.
content.location: This is located along the backside of the rocky plateau on top of Laddin’s Rock that runs parallel to the cliff line.  On the far left side of plateau as you face Laddin’s Rock Road you will find a tree with the purple spray painted counsel “Love is Love”

climbs.name: A Laddin Sane
climbs.fa: Felix Modugno, early 1980's, with some pre-placed gear

content.description: climb the crack with gear
content.protection: Standard rack to .75ish camalot and a #3 blue camalot   Offset stoppers/rp's/small to medium stoppers
content.location: Just left of the diagonal crack of First Aid. Decent: Rappel from anchors, scramble off left (not advised), or climb up the airy face above (5.8 or 5.10 R).

content.description: Start at the low hold (don't dab), throw right to the sidepull, and from there go straight up. on the 2nd rail travel left until the slope
content.protection: 1 pad
content.location: All the way on the right of Laddin's Rock

content.description:
Tucked away in the Laddin's Rock Sanctuary in a residential neighborhood in Old Greenwich, lies a 60 foot crystally granite wall, with several routes on it. The wall is hidden by the canopy of the forest from the sun. The rock has a tendency to be wet in areas due to run-off from above. The only real crowd one might expect to see are people walking their dogs. Interesting enough, there are several rusty pitons scattered in different parts of the wall. There are also a bunch of boulders in this area as well. There are several trad climbs, and everything is top ropeable. Several classic lines now have fixed anchors to minimize rope drag and prevent further erosion on top of the cliff. Otherwise, extended anchors to minimize rope drag may be necessary. This crag is also a great location for folks who have learned to climb in the gym and want to take their first steps to climb outside. It's has something for everyone: classic cracks, heady trad routes, mixed routes, and boulders.

 Crag maintenance: Due to the location of this crag, other user groups including graffiti "artists", homeless people and people that like to leave their trash and broken bottles everywhere, it will quickly become grungy and disgusting. Upon visiting, please pack out any trash or broken glass that you might find during your visit. If we can all take care of this great little historical piece of rock, we can ensure a fun experience for the local climbing community.

 Local ethics: This is one of CT's most historical crags, seeing many of its first free ascents in the 1970's and 80's. While there is still room for new free routes on the wall, any new routes requiring fixed hardware (i.e., bolts) must be done on lead. Rap-bolting is not permitted. Hardware placed next to natural pro is also not permitted. New routes not following these ethics will be chopped.
